paragraphs.body: This page contains references made to ${link_0} in popular culture, such as in movies, television, and video games.
section: List of Avatar: The Last Airbender references in popular culture
paragraphs.text: This page contains references made to Avatar: The Last Airbender in popular culture, such as in movies, television, and video games.

paragraphs.body: In the episode "Blood on the Tracks", Sean, Stillman's grandson, has an Aang toy, and states that he can bend air.

paragraphs.body: In the first episode "${link_0}", Claudia can be seen reading a book titled ${link_1}; the series is co-created by ${link_2}, who was the former head writer for Avatar: The Last Airbender.

paragraphs.body: In the episode "${link_0}", there is a skit called "Airbender Technical Institute", a clear parody of Avatar: The Last Airbender.

links.body: The Social Netjerk / Smallville: Turn Off the Clark

section: List of Avatar: The Last Airbender references in popular culture
paragraphs.text: In the episode "The Social Netjerk / Smallville: Turn Off the Clark", there is a skit called "Airbender Technical Institute", a clear parody of Avatar: The Last Airbender.

paragraphs.body: In a later episode "${link_0}", there is a skit called "Legend of Dora", a reference to The Legend of Korra.
section: List of Avatar: The Last Airbender references in popular culture
paragraphs.text: In a later episode "Average-ers / Legend of Dora", there is a skit called "Legend of Dora", a reference to The Legend of Korra.

paragraphs.body: In the episode "${link_0}", Mary Ferry accuses Addie of making fun of her Avatar: The Last Airbender themed birthday party. She even goes on to say that Addie will be sorry for missing out on the party when she hears how much fun they had playing "pin the tail on ${link_1} ${link_2} in the Land of ${link_3}."
section: List of Avatar: The Last Airbender references in popular culture
paragraphs.text: In the episode "The Two Timer", Mary Ferry accuses Addie of making fun of her Avatar: The Last Airbender themed birthday party. She even goes on to say that Addie will be sorry for missing out on the party when she hears how much fun they had playing "pin the tail on King Bumi in the Land of Omashu."

paragraphs.body: In ${link_0}, Horatio says to Gulliver (referring to one of his made-up adventures): "When you became the Avatar ...".

paragraphs.text: In Gulliver's Travels, Horatio says to Gulliver (referring to one of his made-up adventures): "When you became the Avatar ...".

paragraphs.body: Toward the end of the film ${link_0}, Jess is shown putting on an Avatar: The Last Airbender backpack. The film was directed by ${link_1} who also directed ${link_2}.
section: List of Avatar: The Last Airbender references in popular culture
paragraphs.text: Toward the end of the film The Happening, Jess is shown putting on an Avatar: The Last Airbender backpack. The film was directed by M. Night Shyamalan who also directed The Last Airbender.

paragraphs.body: In ${link_0}, Avatar: The Last Airbender is mentioned in dialogue.
section: List of Avatar: The Last Airbender references in popular culture
paragraphs.text: In Spoof Movie No Jutsu!, Avatar: The Last Airbender is mentioned in dialogue.

paragraphs.body: In ${link_0}, Ginny says to Harry, "We kissed at the Yule Ball and ... well ... I thought we were going to be together forever, but we're not." This is similar to when ${link_1} told ${link_2}, "We kissed at the ${link_3} and I thought we were going to be together, but we're not," in "${link_4}".
section: List of Avatar: The Last Airbender references in popular culture
paragraphs.text: In Act 2, Part 1, Ginny says to Harry, "We kissed at the Yule Ball and ... well ... I thought we were going to be together forever, but we're not." This is similar to when Aang told Katara, "We kissed at the invasion and I thought we were going to be together, but we're not," in "The Ember Island Players".

paragraphs.body: In ${link_0}, Ron asks Hermione, "What if we don't come back?" to which she replies, "Ron! Don't say that! You-" but is interrupted by Ron kissing her. This is similar to when Aang asks Katara, "What if- What if I don't come back?" to which she replies, "Aang, don't say that. Of course you'll-" but is interrupted when Aang kisses her in "${link_1}".

links.body: The Day of Black Sun, Part 1: The Invasion

section: List of Avatar: The Last Airbender references in popular culture
paragraphs.text: In Act 2, Part 5, Ron asks Hermione, "What if we don't come back?" to which she replies, "Ron! Don't say that! You-" but is interrupted by Ron kissing her. This is similar to when Aang asks Katara, "What if- What if I don't come back?" to which she replies, "Aang, don't say that. Of course you'll-" but is interrupted when Aang kisses her in "The Day of Black Sun, Part 1: The Invasion".

paragraphs.body: In ${link_0}, before Voldemort kills Harry, he tells Harry, "You're weak ... weak just like your parents. They did not deserve to live in this world, in my world! Prepare to join them! Prepare to die!" This is similar to when ${link_1} says to Aang, "You're weak! Just like the rest of your ${link_2}. They did not deserve to exist in this world, in my world! Prepare to join them! Prepare to die!" in "${link_3}".

links.body: Sozin's Comet, Part 3: Into the Inferno

section: List of Avatar: The Last Airbender references in popular culture
paragraphs.text: In Act 2, Part 7, before Voldemort kills Harry, he tells Harry, "You're weak ... weak just like your parents. They did not deserve to live in this world, in my world! Prepare to join them! Prepare to die!" This is similar to when Ozai says to Aang, "You're weak! Just like the rest of your people. They did not deserve to exist in this world, in my world! Prepare to join them! Prepare to die!" in "Sozin's Comet, Part 3: Into the Inferno".

paragraphs.body: In ${link_0}, Ron says to Harry, "That's rough, buddy." This is word-for-word what ${link_1} says to ${link_2} in "${link_3}".
section: List of Avatar: The Last Airbender references in popular culture
paragraphs.text: In Act 2, Part 1, Ron says to Harry, "That's rough, buddy." This is word-for-word what Zuko says to Sokka in "The Boiling Rock, Part 1".

paragraphs.body: In ${link_0}, Ron reminds Hermione, "The Draco we know always has an ulterior motive." Draco replies, "That's strange. I have no ulterior motive." He promptly feigns a tired stretch that looks exactly like the one ${link_1} does during the following dialogue: "You have another motive for doing this. I just haven't figured out what it is." "Please, Zuko. What ulterior motive could I have?" For a side-by-side comparison, see ${link_2}.
section: List of Avatar: The Last Airbender references in popular culture
paragraphs.text: In Act 2, Part 6, Ron reminds Hermione, "The Draco we know always has an ulterior motive." Draco replies, "That's strange. I have no ulterior motive." He promptly feigns a tired stretch that looks exactly like the one Azula does during the following dialogue: "You have another motive for doing this. I just haven't figured out what it is." "Please, Zuko. What ulterior motive could I have?" For a side-by-side comparison, see this video.

paragraphs.body: In ${link_0}, Lucius and Draco's conversation about Draco's real father includes the following dialogue: "Coward! ... Don't you want to know who your real father is?" [...] "So he's still alive?" "Perhaps. But now I see that banishment is far too merciful a penalty. Yours shall be far steeper!" This is similar to Ozai and Zuko's conversation including the following dialogue: "Coward! ... Don't you want to know what happened to your mother?" [...] "So she's alive?" "Perhaps. But now I see that banishment is far too merciful a penalty for treason. Yours shall be far steeper," in "${link_1}".

links.body: The Day of Black Sun, Part 2: The Eclipse

section: List of Avatar: The Last Airbender references in popular culture
paragraphs.text: In Act 2, Part 11, Lucius and Draco's conversation about Draco's real father includes the following dialogue: "Coward! ... Don't you want to know who your real father is?" [...] "So he's still alive?" "Perhaps. But now I see that banishment is far too merciful a penalty. Yours shall be far steeper!" This is similar to Ozai and Zuko's conversation including the following dialogue: "Coward! ... Don't you want to know what happened to your mother?" [...] "So she's alive?" "Perhaps. But now I see that banishment is far too merciful a penalty for treason. Yours shall be far steeper," in "The Day of Black Sun, Part 2: The Eclipse".

paragraphs.body: In ${link_0}, Hermione tells Draco, "No, I can't forgive him. But I think it's about time that I forgave you." This is similar to when Katara tells Aang, "But I didn't forgive him. I'll never forgive him", before telling Zuko, "But I am ready to forgive you," in "${link_1}".
section: List of Avatar: The Last Airbender references in popular culture
paragraphs.text: In Act 2, Part 13, Hermione tells Draco, "No, I can't forgive him. But I think it's about time that I forgave you." This is similar to when Katara tells Aang, "But I didn't forgive him. I'll never forgive him", before telling Zuko, "But I am ready to forgive you," in "The Southern Raiders".

paragraphs.body: The comic strip ${link_0} pokes fun at the controversy surrounding the casting of the live action film, in particular the actor playing Aang, and suggests that M. Night Shyamalan has cast Morgan Freeman as ${link_1}, with the veteran actor not wearing a suit and "just flying around".
section: List of Avatar: The Last Airbender references in popular culture
paragraphs.text: The comic strip Heresies pokes fun at the controversy surrounding the casting of the live action film, in particular the actor playing Aang, and suggests that M. Night Shyamalan has cast Morgan Freeman as Appa, with the veteran actor not wearing a suit and "just flying around".

paragraphs.body: In this app, the quest "Class Act" has a reference to ${link_0} as Payton states she was the one who stopped M. Night Shyamalan from making a sequel to the Avatar movie. The "Rumble of the Clans" quest also has the main character stating, "I am the Avatar", as they compete in a video game using bending-like powers. When in need for a team name in another question, the characters chose ${link_1}. The game's voting system, The Dish, also asks the player what element they would wield if they could bend and which Nickelodeon character their favorite is, with ${link_2} being an option.
section: List of Avatar: The Last Airbender references in popular culture
paragraphs.text: In this app, the quest "Class Act" has a reference to The Last Airbender as Payton states she was the one who stopped M. Night Shyamalan from making a sequel to the Avatar movie. The "Rumble of the Clans" quest also has the main character stating, "I am the Avatar", as they compete in a video game using bending-like powers. When in need for a team name in another question, the characters chose Fire Ferrets. The game's voting system, The Dish, also asks the player what element they would wield if they could bend and which Nickelodeon character their favorite is, with Korra being an option.

paragraphs.body: Male ${link_0} have a hair style option called "The Sokka", which resembles Sokka's hair from the first season.
section: List of Avatar: The Last Airbender references in popular culture
paragraphs.text: Male Pandaren have a hair style option called "The Sokka", which resembles Sokka's hair from the first season.

paragraphs.body: In the episode "${link_0}", ${link_1}'s work was stated, including Avatar: The Last Airbender. The Critic also mentioned Mako in the episode "${link_2}", in which he apologized for joking in his review of the 2007 Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles film that "[Mako playing Splinter] sounds like Mr. Miyagi if he smoked a pack of Marlboros", not knowing at the time that Mako had died of oesophageal cancer.
section: List of Avatar: The Last Airbender references in popular culture
paragraphs.text: In the episode "Red Sonja", Mako Iwamatsu's work was stated, including Avatar: The Last Airbender. The Critic also mentioned Mako in the episode "Top 11 Nostalgia Critic F*ckups", in which he apologized for joking in his review of the 2007 Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles film that "[Mako playing Splinter] sounds like Mr. Miyagi if he smoked a pack of Marlboros", not knowing at the time that Mako had died of oesophageal cancer.

paragraphs.body: In his review of ${link_0}, the Nostalgia Critic states Katara's line, "Then everything changed when the Fire Nation attacked", as a joke to the similarly narrated opening of the anime.
section: List of Avatar: The Last Airbender references in popular culture
paragraphs.text: In his review of Sailor Moon, the Nostalgia Critic states Katara's line, "Then everything changed when the Fire Nation attacked", as a joke to the similarly narrated opening of the anime.

paragraphs.body: He has used the running gags of "my cabbages" and "${link_0}" in multiple reviews.
section: List of Avatar: The Last Airbender references in popular culture
paragraphs.text: He has used the running gags of "my cabbages" and "foaming mouth guy" in multiple reviews.

paragraphs.body: His ${link_0} of The Last Airbender features a parody of M. Night Shyamalan based heavily on ${link_1}. This parody of Shyamalan also appears in his reviews of ${link_2} and ${link_3}, which were produced and directed by M. Night. He shows up again as a cameo in the critics review of Pixels, and has appeared in several other videos since. In the same review, his two co-actors, Malcolm Ray and Rachel Tietz, make several appearances dressed as comedic parodies of Sokka and Katara.
section: List of Avatar: The Last Airbender references in popular culture
paragraphs.text: His review of The Last Airbender features a parody of M. Night Shyamalan based heavily on Amon. This parody of Shyamalan also appears in his reviews of Devil and After Earth, which were produced and directed by M. Night. He shows up again as a cameo in the critics review of Pixels, and has appeared in several other videos since. In the same review, his two co-actors, Malcolm Ray and Rachel Tietz, make several appearances dressed as comedic parodies of Sokka and Katara.

paragraphs.body: ${link_0} makes his first appearance at the end of ${link_1}, in which he is informed of the critic's list and parodizes ${link_2} first appearance in ${link_3}. The following weeks, Basco appears as an over-the-top parody of his animated counterpart Zuko in the episode "${link_4}", chasing the critic through a Barnes and Noble screaming the word "honor". In the same episode, the critic also makes a reference to ${link_5} and ${link_6}, who are seen on book covers, distracts Dante with a copy of The Search trilogy, and mistakes Dante as Zuko for ${link_7}, who portrayed Zuko in the film. Malcolm Ray also reprises his role as Sokka in order to distract Basco, and Rachel's replacement, Tamara Chambers, makes an appearance dressed as Toph.

links.body: Top 11 Avatar The Last Airbender Episodes

section: List of Avatar: The Last Airbender references in popular culture
paragraphs.text: Dante Basco makes his first appearance at the end of Top 11 Worst Avatar Episodes, in which he is informed of the critic's list and parodizes General Iroh's first appearance in The Legend of Korra. The following weeks, Basco appears as an over-the-top parody of his animated counterpart Zuko in the episode "Top 11 Avatar The Last Airbender Episodes", chasing the critic through a Barnes and Noble screaming the word "honor". In the same episode, the critic also makes a reference to Kisu and Manuel Rodriguez, who are seen on book covers, distracts Dante with a copy of The Search trilogy, and mistakes Dante as Zuko for Dev Patel, who portrayed Zuko in the film. Malcolm Ray also reprises his role as Sokka in order to distract Basco, and Rachel's replacement, Tamara Chambers, makes an appearance dressed as Toph.

paragraphs.body: In his review of ${link_0}, he can be seen petting a plush toy of Appa. The same plush would later appear as the adorable pet mascot for the Token Troop, a group he put together in order to review the movie Monster Squad.
section: List of Avatar: The Last Airbender references in popular culture
paragraphs.text: In his review of Demolition Man, he can be seen petting a plush toy of Appa. The same plush would later appear as the adorable pet mascot for the Token Troop, a group he put together in order to review the movie Monster Squad.

paragraphs.body: In the episode "${link_0}", The Big Five mentions that reruns from Avatar: The Last Airbender could serve as a replacement for the canceled Yu-Gi-Oh series.
section: List of Avatar: The Last Airbender references in popular culture
paragraphs.text: In the episode "Beyond the Fourth Wall", The Big Five mentions that reruns from Avatar: The Last Airbender could serve as a replacement for the canceled Yu-Gi-Oh series.
